columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the net present value and the internal rate of return of the given project based on the data provided.

The net present value measures the profitability of a project based on the inflows and outflows of cash in a given time. A positive net present value means that the inflow of cash is higher than the outflow, thus, the project is profitable. 

On the other hand, the internal rate of return is also a measure of the profitability of a company or a project based on its net present value.

The first step that we need to do is to solve for the annual sales. This can be done by multiplying the quantity sold by the sale price.


For **Year 1**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=73,000 \times \$375\\[15 pt]
&=\$27,375,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 1 is $\$27,375,000$

For **Year 2**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=86,000 \times \$375\\[15 pt]
&=\$32,250,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 2 is $\$32,250,000$

For **Year 3**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=105,000 \times \$375\\[15 pt]
&=\$39,375,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 3 is $\$39,375,000$

For **Year 4**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=97,000 \times \$375\\[15 pt]
&=\$36,375,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 4 is $\$36,375,000$

For **Year 5**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Annual sales}&=67,000 \times \$375\\[15 pt]
&=\$25,125,000
\end{aligned}$$

The sales for Year 5 is $\$25,125,000$

Next is the depreciation. In this case, we will use the Modified Accelerated Cash Recovery System wherein the initial investment is multiplied to a fixed factor every year. The factors for a 5-year MACRS depreciation are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.1429\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.2449\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.1749\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.1249\\
\text{Year 5}&=0.0893
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the depreciation.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$16,500,000 \times 0.1429\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,357,850
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 1 is $\$2,357,850$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$16,500,000 \times 0.2449\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,040,850
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 2 is $\$4,040,850$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$16,500,000 \times 0.1749\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,885,850
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 3 is $\$2,885,850$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$16,500,000 \times 0.1249\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,060,850
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 4 is $\$2,060,850$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$16,500,000 \times 0.0893\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,473,450
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 5 is $\$1,473,450$

For the variable cost, we can simply take the number of units sold then multiply it by the variable cost per unit which is $\$255$.

For **Year 1**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$255 \times 73,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$18,615,000
\end{aligned}$$

For **Year 2**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$255 \times 86,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$21,930,000
\end{aligned}$$

For **Year 3**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$255 \times 105,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$26,775,000
\end{aligned}$$

For **Year 4**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$255 \times 97,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$24,735,000
\end{aligned}$$

For **Year 5**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost}&=\$255 \times 67,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$17,085,000
\end{aligned}$$

Now, we can solve for the earnings before interest and tax (EBIT). To do this, we will simply take the annual sales then, subtract the fixed cost, variable cost, and the depreciation.

For **Year 1**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\$27,375,000-\$3,200,000-\$18,615,000-\$2,357,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,202,150
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 1 is $\$3,202,150$

For **Year 2**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\$32,250,000-\$3,200,000-\$21,930,000-\$4,040,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,079,150
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 2 is $\$3,079,150$

For **Year 3**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\$39,375,000-\$3,200,000-\$26,775,000-\$2,885,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$6,514,150
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 3 is $\$6,514,150$

For **Year 4**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\$36,375,000-\$3,200,000-\$24,735,000-\$2,060,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$6,406,150
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 4 is $\$6,406,150$

For **Year 5**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\$25,125,000-\$3,200,000-\$17,085,000-\$1,473,450\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,366,550
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings before interest and tax for Year 5 is $\$3,366,550$

Since we already have the EBIT, we can now solve for the net income by multiplying this value by one minus the tax rate.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$3,202,150 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,529,698.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 1 is $\$2,529,698.50$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$3,079,150 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,432,528.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 2 is $\$2,432,528.50$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$6,514,150 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,146,178.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 3 is $\$5,146,178.50$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$6,406,150 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,060,858.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 4 is $\$5,060,858.50$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$3,366,550 \times (1-0.21)\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,659,574.50
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 5 is $\$2,659,574.50$

Next, to get the operating cash flow for each year, we will simply add back the depreciation to the net income.

For **Year 1**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 1}&=\$2,529,698.50+\$2,357,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,887,548.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cashflow for Year 1 is $\$4,887,548.50$

For **Year 2**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 2}&=\$2,432,528.50+\$4,040,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$6,473,378.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cashflow for Year 2 is $\$6,473,378.50$

For **Year 3**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 3}&=\$5,146,178.50+\$2,885,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$8,032,028.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cashflow for Year 3 is $\$8,032,028.50$

For **Year 4**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 4}&=\$5,060,858.50+\$2,060,850\\[15 pt]
&=\$7,121,708.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cashflow for Year 4 is $\$7,121,708.50$

For **Year 5**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow Year 5}&=\$2,659,574.50+\$1,473,450\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,133,024.50
\end{aligned}$$

The cashflow for Year 5 is $\$4,133,024.50$

In order for us to solve the total cash inflow for each year, we must first solve for the net working capital. It is stated that the net working capital is $15%$ of the net increase for the following year. This means that the formula for the net working capital is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=0.15\times(\text{Annual sales for the following year}-\text{Annual sales for the current year})
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the net working capital, we will get these:

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=0.15\times(\$32,250,000-\$27,375,000)\\[15 pt]
&=\$731,250
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 1 is $\$731,250$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=0.15\times(\$39,375,000-\$32,250,000)\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,068,750
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 2 is $\$1,068,750$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=0.15\times(\$36,375,000-\$39,375,000)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$450,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 3 is $-\$450,000$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=0.15\times(\$25,125,000-\$36,375,000)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$1,687,500
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 4 is $-\$1,687,500$

For the net working capital for Year 5, we will take the sum of the net working capital of Year 1 to 4 then subtract this from the initial net working capital.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital}&=\$1,500,000-\$731,250\\
&-\$1,068,750+\$450,000\\
&+\$1,687,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,837,500
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 5 is $\$1,837,500$

Next step here is to get the total cash inflow per year by taking the operating cash flow and subtracting the net working capital from it.

For **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Inflow for Year 1}&=\$4,887,548.50-\$731,250\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,156,298.50
\end{aligned}$$

The Inflow for Year 1 is $\$4,156,298.50$

For **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Inflow for Year 2}&=\$6,473,378.50-\$1,068,750\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,404,628.50
\end{aligned}$$

The Inflow for Year 2 is $\$5,404,628.50$

For **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Inflow for Year 3}&=\$8,032,028.50+\$450,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$8,482,028.50
\end{aligned}$$

The Inflow for Year 3 is $\$8,482,028.50$

For **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Inflow for Year 4}&=\$7,121,708.50+\$1,687,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$8,809,208.50
\end{aligned}$$

The Inflow for Year 4 is $\$8,809,208.50$

For **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Inflow for Year 5}&=\$4,133,024.50-\$1,837,500\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,295,524.50
\end{aligned}$$

The Inflow for Year 5 is $\$2,295,524.50$

For the cash outflow, we will simply take the Initial net working capital and the initial investment and add them together.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash outflow}&=\$16,500,000+\$1,500,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$18,000,000
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the known values to the formula in Step 3, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{\$4,156,298.50}{(1+0.18)^1}+\dfrac{\$5,404,628.50}{(1+0.18)^2}\\
&+\dfrac{\$8,482,028.50}{(1+0.18)^3}+\dfrac{\$8,809,208.50}{(1+0.18)^4}\\
&+\dfrac{\$2,295,524.50}{(1+0.18)^5}-\$18,000,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$113,317.97
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this project is $\$113,317.97$

For the internal rate of return, we will use a spreadsheet utility. Simply input the cash inflows for each year. Set the cash inflow for Year 0 as $-\$18,000,000$. Type IRR in the formula bar then highlight all the values. When you click enter, this will be the result:
[![D3-E23618-0457-47-F8-81-EA-2-E2-D1643-C218-4-5005-c.jpg](https://i.postimg.cc/vH6t4h3j/D3-E23618-0457-47-F8-81-EA-2-E2-D1643-C218-4-5005-c.jpg)](https://postimg.cc/1fsqTGxc)

The internal rate of return for this is $18\%$

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
